messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using Java and the RESTEasy/JAX-RS on Netty (resteasy-netty4) for a Java-based REST API framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `src/main/java/com/datastax/mgmtapi/resources/KeyspaceOpsResources.java`, I found that `anonymous` is implemented to process HTTP requests to the path `/api/v0/ops/keyspace`. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
Here is the analysis of the KeyspaceOpsResources endpoint(s) in src/main/java/com/datastax/mgmtapi/resources/KeyspaceOpsResources.java.

1) Full HTTP request paths (prefix + path)
- The class is annotated with @Path("/api/v0/ops/keyspace"), so every endpoint starts with /api/v0/ops/keyspace.
- Endpoints and their full paths:
  - POST /api/v0/ops/keyspace/cleanup
  - POST /api/v0/ops/keyspace/refresh
  - POST /api/v0/ops/keyspace/create
  - POST /api/v0/ops/keyspace/alter
  - GET  /api/v0/ops/keyspace
  - GET  /api/v0/ops/keyspace/replication

Notes on path parameters:
- None of these methods declare path parameters. Therefore no path parameters wrapped in curly braces are needed. The paths above are the exact full paths.

2) Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable
- False. The resource only exposes specific HTTP methods (POST for cleanup/refresh/create/alter and GET for list/replication). There is no support for all methods.

3) HEAD method
- Acceptable: False. There are no @HEAD methods defined; HEAD would rely on framework defaults or behavior, but based strictly on the code, there is no HEAD handler.

4) POST method
- Acceptable: True for the endpoints that declare @POST:
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/cleanup
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/refresh
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/create
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/alter

5) OPTIONS method
- Acceptable: False. No @OPTIONS handler is defined; not handled explicitly in code.

6) TRACE method
- Acceptable: False. No @TRACE handler is defined.

7) GET method
- Acceptable: True for the endpoints that declare @GET:
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/replication

8) PUT method
- Acceptable: False. No @PUT handlers defined.

9) DELETE method
- Acceptable: False. No @DELETE handlers defined.

10) PATCH method
- Acceptable: False. No @PATCH handlers defined.

Explanation
- The endpoints are determined from the class-level @Path and each methodâ€™s HTTP method annotation (@GET or @POST) and their @Path where present.
- There are four POST endpoints (cleanup, refresh, create, alter) and two GET endpoints (list, replication). No other HTTP methods are implemented in this class.
- There are no path parameters in these methods; hence the full paths are straightforward expansions of the class path plus the method-specific path segments.
- HEAD, OPTIONS, TRACE, PUT, DELETE, PATCH are not defined in the code, so they are not considered acceptable based on the code (not just on typical REST semantics).

If you want this reflected in an OpenAPI spec, you would document:
- Paths:
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/cleanup (POST)
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/refresh (POST)
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/create (POST)
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/alter (POST)
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace (GET)
  - /api/v0/ops/keyspace/replication (GET)
- Only POST and GET operations as above; no operations for HEAD/PUT/DELETE/PATCH/OPTIONS/TRACE unless added in code.
